title: Type I & Type II Error Definitions
text: If the sample does not contain E.coli, but the microbiologist thinks it does, this is a Type I error (i.e. The decision is to reject $$H_0$$ when, in fact, $$H_0$$ is true). If the sample does contain E. coli, but the microbiologist thinks it does not, this is a Type II error (i.e. The decision is to not reject $$H_0$$ when, in fact, $$H_0$$ is false).

title: Type II Error and Power
text: Since the problem asks for the power, we need to use the Type II error rate because the two values are related to each other in the equation: $$Power=1-probability$$ of a Type II error

title: Type II Error Rate
text: The probability of a Type II error occuring is the Type II error rate, which is $$0.002$$.

title: Using the Power Equation
text: To solve for the power, plug the Type I error rate into the equation: $$Power=1-probability$$ of a Type II error occurring
